Splitting field of Family of Polynomials

A splitting field of a family of nonconstant polynomials \\(\mathfrak{F}=(f_i)_{i \in I}, f_i \in K[X]\\) over a field \\(K\\) is a field \\(L\\) extending \\(K\\) such that: (i) Every polynomial \\(f_i\\) decomposes into a product of linear factors over \\(L\\). (ii) The extension \\(L / K\\) is generated by the zeros of the polynomials \\(f_i\\).

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.

Explanation: The definition of a normal field extension explicitly states that it is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. This directly implies that the concept of a splitting field is integral to understanding and defining what a normal field extension is. The definition of a normal field extension includes the condition that the extension field \(L\) must be a splitting field for a family of polynomials in \(K[X]\), which is precisely what the concept of a splitting field describes.
